In Julia, Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example

In Julia, you can define a function to wrap text by using the built-in `split` function to split the string into words and then join them back together with newlines when the line length exceeds a certain limit. Here's how you can implement such a function:

```julia
function wrap_string(text::AbstractString; text_width::Int=10)
    words = split(text)
    output = ""
    for word in words
        if length(word) > text_width
            throw(ErrorException("Word is longer than the maximum line width: $word"))
        end
        if output == "" || length(output) + length(word) + 1 > text_width
            # If this word starts a new line, add a newline
            output *= "\n"
        end
        output *= word * ' '
    end
    return output
end
```

This function takes a string `text` and an optional argument `text_width` which specifies the maximum number of characters per line. It splits the text into words using `split`, then iterates over each word. If the current line (including the word) would exceed the specified width, a newline is added before appending the word.

Please note that this function does not handle very long words that are longer than the maximum line width. In such cases, it will throw an `ErrorException`. You may want to truncate or handle these words differently in your application.

Here's an example of how you can use the `wrap_string` function:

```julia
julia> wrap_string("Hello there! This is a very long string that I would like to wrap into multiple lines.")
"Hello there!\nThis is a very long string\nthat I would like to wrap\ninto multiple lines."
```

In this example, the text has been wrapped at the 10-character limit specified by `text_width`.
